title: Conflict & Attachment
description: Discover how your attachment style shapes conflict patterns.

questions.text: When we have a conflict, what's my typical response?
choices: I pursue resolution immediately
I need space to calm down first
I try to fix it right away to feel secure again
I withdraw to protect myself

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict responses are deeply tied to attachment styles. Immediate pursuers have anxious attachment activation; space-needers have avoidant activation; fix-it-now types manage anxiety through action; withdrawers protect through distance. Your conflict response often triggers your partner's attachment system in return.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict responses often create the pursue-withdraw cycle. The immediate pursuer escalates because the withdrawer won't engage; the withdrawer retreats because pursuit feels overwhelming. Name the pattern to break it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict responses can be helpful or problematic. Two pursuers will engage intensely; two withdrawers may avoid necessary conversations. Know your shared pattern.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens in your body when conflict arises? Where did you learn this response? Does it help or hinder resolution?

questions.text: What do I need from you during an argument?
choices: Reassurance that we'll be okay
Space to process my emotions
Active listening and validation
Your calm presence without intensity

therapeutic.rationale: What we need during arguments reveals our attachment soothing system. Reassurance-seekers need attachment confirmation; space-needers need self-regulation time; validation-seekers need to feel heard; calm-presence seekers need co-regulation without escalation. Providing the wrong thing during conflict can escalate rather than resolve.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different argument needs create disconnects. The reassurance-seeker feels abandoned by the space-needer; the space-needer feels suffocated by pursuit. Ask: 'What do you need right now?' before assuming.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared argument needs make de-escalation easier. You'll naturally provide what helps because it's what you need too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: During arguments, what helps you calm down? What makes things worse? Does your partner know what you need?

questions.text: How long do I typically need to process after a disagreement?
choices: I want to resolve it immediately
A few minutes to an hour
Several hours to a day
I move on quickly once it's addressed

therapeutic.rationale: Processing time needs reflect nervous system regulation. Immediate-resolvers have anxiety that needs quick relief; brief-processors need minimal space; extended-processors need time for their system to settle; quick-movers recover fast. Respecting different processing times prevents re-triggering.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different processing times test relationships. The immediate-resolver may feel dismissed by the day-long processor; the extended-processor may feel pressured by immediate demands. Negotiate timing explicitly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared processing times smooth post-conflict recovery. You'll naturally be ready to reconnect at similar moments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How long does it take you to feel calm after conflict? What happens if you're pushed to resolve before you're ready?

questions.text: What helps me feel safe enough to resolve conflicts with you?
choices: Knowing you're committed to working it out
Your calm and respectful approach
Feeling heard and understood
Confidence that you won't leave

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict safety needs reveal core attachment requirements. Commitment-knowing addresses abandonment anxiety; calm-approach needs reflect sensitivity to dysregulation; feeling-heard addresses validation needs; won't-leave confidence addresses foundational security. Without these conditions, conflicts feel existentially threatening rather than solvable.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different safety needs mean you need different things to engage. Create your partner's safety conditions.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared safety needs make conflict feel less dangerous. You understand what each other needs to feel secure enough to engage.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes conflict feel safe versus threatening? Can you engage when you don't feel safe? What would help you feel more secure?

questions.text: What's my biggest fear during a conflict?
choices: That it will damage our relationship
That you'll pull away from me
That we won't understand each other
That the issue won't truly get resolved

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict fears reveal attachment vulnerabilities. Damage-fear indicates catastrophizing about relationship fragility; pull-away fear indicates abandonment anxiety; misunderstanding fear indicates connection anxiety; unresolved-fear indicates completion anxiety. Knowing your partner's conflict fear helps you provide specific reassurance.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict fears drive different protective behaviors. The damage-fearer may avoid all conflict; the pull-away fearer may pursue intensely. Understanding fear motivations increases compassion.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict fears create mutual understanding but may also reinforce avoidance patterns. Two damage-fearers may avoid necessary conversations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your deepest fear when you and your partner conflict? Where does this fear come from? Is the fear realistic?
